definitions.definition: an accepted way of behaving or of doing things in a society or a community
definitions.sensetop: according to customcustom of doing somethingit is the custom for somebody to do something

examples.text: It's a **local custom**.
an ancient custom
a burial/marriage custom
a tribal custom
She grew up with Chinese customs and traditions.
According to custom, one son inherited all the family property.
Widows **observed the custom** of wearing black.
It is the custom in that country for women to marry young.
examples.contextForm: it is the custom for somebody to do something

examples.text: The custom died out in the nineteenth century.
The rules have grown up through custom and are not laid down by law.
These customs still prevail in remote areas.
They poured wine around the trees in accordance with local custom.
They still follow the custom of pinning money to the bride's dress.
It is the custom here to put flowers on the graves at Easter.
The custom of using Latin for legal records came to an end.
They were unfamiliar with local customs and culture.
the custom of giving presents at Christmas
Guyanese custom dictates that the child be given a piece of gold jewellery for good luck soon after birth.

definitions.definition: the way a person always behaves

examples.text: It was her custom to rise early.
As was his custom, he knocked three times.
It is my custom to keep my word.
They were seated, as was their custom, in the summer house.
He then repeated the question, as his custom was.

definitions.definition: the fact of a person or people buying goods or services at a shop or business
definitions.labels: (British English, formal)North American English, British English

examples.text: Thank you for your custom. Please call again.
We've lost a lot of custom since prices went up.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French coustume, based on Latin consuetudo, from consuetus, past participle of consuescere ‘accustom’, from con- (expressing intensive force) + suescere ‘become accustomed’.
